A dazzlingly bloody and vengeful rampage, Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill Vol. 1 delivers a high-octane thrill ride that's drenched in homage to classic martial arts and grindhouse cinema. This stylish revenge tale pulls no punches, and audiences will find themselves gasping for breath as they're dragged through an enthralling whirlwind of non-stop action and mesmerizing visuals.

The narrative centres on Uma Thurman's enigmatic character, The Bride, who embarks on a brutal quest for vengeance against her former teammates and their manipulative leader, Bill. Thurman delivers a powerhouse performance, showcasing her physical prowess and dramatic range as she slices her way through a rogue's gallery of eccentric and dangerous foes.

Tarantino's distinctive directorial style is on full display, as he weaves together a tapestry of flashbacks, expertly choreographed fight sequences, and a razor-sharp script. Kill Bill Vol. 1 is an unapologetic love letter to genre cinema, with nods to spaghetti westerns, kung Fu classics, and Japanese samurai films, all underscored by an eclectic soundtrack that will leave your pulse pounding.

The supporting cast is equally as impressive, with Lucy Liu, Vivica A. Fox, Daryl Hannah, and David Carradine each bringing their respective characters to life with a unique blend of menace and charisma. Special mention must go to the visually arresting set piece that pits Thurman against the deadly Crazy 88, showcasing the creative collaboration between Tarantino and legendary fight choreographer Yuen Woo-Ping.

Though not for the faint of heart, Kill Bill Vol. 1 is a masterclass in filmmaking that revels in its excesses and pushes the boundaries of genre cinema. With its relentless pace, unforgettable characters, and astonishing action sequences, this is one cinematic experience that demands to be seen on the big screen.

Director Quentin Tarantino's martial arts revenge thriller Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003) remains an iconic picture. His chaotic and refined style is so dope. From authentic samurai swordplay to insane kung fu fight choreography, Kill Bill is as versatile as it is entertaining. Tarantino lets his love of cinema history and numerous genres guide his bloody path to entertain us throughout Kill Bill. He has drama, moments of humor, and intense action to grip even the most cynical viewer to his frenetic direction. Kill Bill is Tarantino basically adapting Lady Snowblood into a fierce revenge thriller with ruthless intent in Kill Bill.

Tarantino's writing is a fascinating declaration of Quentin's love of martial arts films like 36th Chamber of Shaolin, Five Deadly Venoms, Game of Death, to the obvious inspiration of Lady Snowblood. He delivers a killer mash-up of poignant revenge thrillers, gory martial arts swordplay, samurai dramas, and even Spaghetti Westerns like Once Upon a Time in the West. It's so strange that it will go from a blaxploitation kung fu fight to an actual anime sequence from Japan's Production I.G. in visceral style. Tarantino's writing centers around The Bride's inner torment after losing her child, being betrayed, and dealing with her righteous fury. Revenge, forgiveness, and dedication are all major themes in Kill Bill. In combining so many genres, Tarantino makes something new.

Editor Sally Menke's frenetic cutting style can do both hectic sword fights to smooth and gentle conversations. Kill Bill therefore has both a brisk action revenge thriller pace as well as a slow burn contemplative dramatic feel as The Bride prepares for her bloody vengeance. Cinematographer Robert Richardson has the most stunning close-up shots of Uma Thurman and Lucy Liu's breathtaking eyes. I loved the weird angles and perspectives as the camera suddenly shifted to bird's eye perspective above or pan in sweeping motions around a room full of danger. Kill Bill may be Quentin Tarantino's best shot film in hindsight.

Uma Thurman's sheer determination to revenge is enthralling as The Bride. Thurman's hurt filled eyes show off a lethal fierceness and tender heartbreak. Her agonized wails are chilling as her bloodthirsty swordplay is exciting. Kill Bill is still Uma Thurman's greatest acting performance. She is hypnotizing and beautiful as Tarantino's ruthless revenge seeker The Bride.

Lucy Liu is jaw-droppingly gorgeous as villainess Yakuza leader O-Ren Ishii. Her looks that could kill are mesmerizing with her piercing eyes, harsh words, and dreamy visage. Liu excels as a commanding Yakuza mob boss along with her elegant swordplay. I am amazed by Lucy Liu in Kill Bill and find she steals every scene. Her tragic backstory and sharp performance make her sympathetic just like Thurman's empathetic Bride. I adore Lucy Liu and wish she got other major leading roles like her unforgettable villainess turn in Kill Bill.

David Carradine's deep voice is remarkable and brings a heavy gravitas to the unseen villain Bill, who Uma Thurman seeks to assassinate for his betrayal. Vivica A. Fox is sultry and fierce as Vernita Green with her care for her daughter and relentless assault against The Bride. Michael Madsen's mysterious Budd and Daryl Hannah's pretty antagonist Elle Driver are memorable and are set up nicely for Kill Bill: Vol. 2. Julie Dreyfus is excellent as the posh Sofie Fatale with her fun French swearing and Japanese translations.

Sonny Chiba's kind and funny swordsmith Hattori Hanzō is a blast. It tells me a lot that Tarantino actually got an old Hollywood legend of martial arts for Kill Bill. He feels nice, wise, experienced, and reflective. Chiaki Kuriyama is cute and crazy as O-Ren's ball and chain wielding bodyguard Gogo Yubari. Martial arts acting icon Gordon Liu has a nice supporting role as Crazy 88 head Johnny Mo, who unleashes endless men and attacks against The Bride. Michael Bowen's vile orderly Buck is truly loathsome. Jun Kunimura is excellent as the upset Yakuza Boss Tanaka, who is upset that Lucy Liu's lovely O-Ren is a foreigner. Kenji Ohba's complaints as Hattori's sake fetcher Shiro is a riot. I enjoyed the cameo from Japanese girl rock group The 5.6.7.8's with their strange blend of surf rock, rockabilly, and punk rock.

Production designers David Wasco and Yohei Taneda create desolate Western churches, sleek Japanese Yakuza hideouts, and cozy Japanese restaurant sets for Kill Bill. It all looks authentic and mesmerizing. Art direction from Daniel Bradford, Minoru Nishida, Cao Juiping, Hidefumi Hanatani, Lu Yo Lui, and Satoko Saito create slick anime sequences and visceral storyboards. Nothing looks like the gritty neo-noir Western or Japanese samurai revenge thriller aesthetic of Kill Bill. Set decorators Sandy Reynolds-Wasco, Yoshihito Akatsuka, Takashi Sasaki, Mary Saisselin, Peter Davidson, and David Ladish provide realistic props for Japanese bars or katanas on racks for an authentic feel for Kill Bill.

Visual effects artists Frankie Chung, Katsuhito Ishii, and Tommy Tom deliver a sick anime flashback for O'Ren Ishii's tragic and bloody backstory. It's like watching violent combat from Afro Samurai or Samurai Champloo. I loved the massive blood splatters whenever The Bride would dismember someone with her katana or cut someone in half. The violence often looks real.

Composer RZA of Wu-Tang Clan really delivers a beautiful film score for Kill Bill. His ear for swelling symphonic melodies mixed in with harder hip hop drum beats is insane. He carefully provides a melancholic requiem for The Bride as she quests for revenge with venom in her heart. I never knew the Kill Bill theme song was really composed by Bernard Herrmann and was entitled "Twisted Nerve," thanks to the subtitles.

Sound designers Harry Cohen, Scott Martin Gershin, Bob Beher, Dino Dimuro, Wylie Stateman, Peter Michael Sullivan, Michael Minkler, John Bires, and Daniel R. Kerr hilariously goes overboard with the shimmering sword sound effects to incessant Wilhelm screams. I liked the bowling pins getting knocked over noises to the loud thuds of a ball and chain hitting The Bride.

Costume designers Catherine Marie Thomas, Kumiko Ogawa, Helen Monaghan, Kanani Wolf, Daniel Grant North, Mark Zunino, and Alexander AD provide iconic yellow jumpsuits for Uma Thurman's The Bride like Bruce Lee's outfit in Game of Death to stunning white kimonos for Lucy Liu's O-Ren Ishii. I loved the striking make-up from artists Ilona Herman, Scott Patton, and Heba Thorisdottir, especially for Uma and Lucy. They simply look marvelous!

Overall, Kill Bill has persevered as a magnificent film full of homages to past pictures and a pleasant mixture of genres with Tarantino's frenetic style. It is a blistering 111 mins of iconic imagery, songs, fights, and fearsome vengeance.

This first half of a blistering revenge story delivers a cacophony of varying styles and influences seared into Tarantino's beautifully crazy mind to make something almost entirely original yet manages to stay remarkably cohesive and focused. The story of revenge is an incredibly appealing concept for the plot of a movie and "Kill Bill: Volume 1" is no different. Uma Thurman has never been better. She makes "The Bride" feel so real, emotional and just a plain-badass. From the opening moments to the cliffhanger ending, I was so enthralled in her plight. The prolonged, climactic "House of Blue Leaves" sequence is worth the price of admission. A masterwork in action/camera choreography. I was a bit disappointed at first about the final fight between "The Bride" and O-Ren Ishii because of the building anticipation through the film and I wished there was a bit more movement involved as oppose to long pauses. But I realized shortly the whole fight thrives on the suspense in the moment, seeing two formidable warriors measuring each other out, looking for an opportunity to make a hit while being very vigilant of what they opponent is about to do; very reminiscent of shogun showdowns and gun duels of the Old Wild West. So it is refreshing to see a fight that shows more restraint for once and it sizzles. Some can argue this movie functions entirely on flash and style with limited substance and some cartoonish over the top violence. This isn't meant to be all that thought-provoking but it utilizes some of the best qualities of Tarantino's filmmaking: being unpredictable, brisk, vibrantly-shot and masterfully entertaining. This was meant to be an generous, ultra stylish teaser before the actual story to kick and I was begging to see more! - 9/10 (A-)

I'm going to review these two volumes as one film, as they were intended. They complete each other in so many ways that I think it would be a completely unfair disservice not to, as I would give them both lower scores individually as they have flaws that the other volume makes up for in spades. This was originally intended as a 4 hour epic and BOY does it feel like one without ever slowing down pacing-wise like any movie half as long tends to feel trying to get the same approach. There's a very cheesy, self-indulgent, ultraviolent quality to volume 1 that's endearing and a wise, heartfelt finale with more restraint in the second that balance out perfectly. Together, you can't complain about the heartless violence when you want something more thoughtful or the lack thereof of the former in a revenge flick in the later because you've already had it. I personally prefer volume 2 over 1 because I enjoy the emotional attachment and the brains attached to what seemed like just a silly martial arts movie structured like a video game. It's all so well filmed and made that together make me want to rewatch the whole bloody affair just talking about it. But independently, yes, you could complain that volume 2 is anticlimactic as there's not much violence and that volume 1 is too violent too early, but together you get more than you asked for. Together, long stretches in volume 2 feel like small footnotes in a larger journey, the way they're intended to by the ten chapter structure. Together, this is a pretty complete film. If there's one thing we've learned about Quentin Tarantino as a screenwriter and director is that one should never expect a typical movie that fits the stereotypes of the genre exactly - or even remotely. We had it with Reservoir Dogs, a heist film where we never see the heist, and with both Pulp Fiction and Inglorious Basterds - two more films which take what is typical and throw it aside.

After multiple views, I still say that Kill Bill Vol. 1 is by far the stronger half of the duo. The entirety of Volume 1 is very much a build up that never fully stops, which is unique even to revenge flicks as they usually ebb and flow with a lot of changes to the pace. Not so here.

Here was have Tarantino at his flashiest but supplemented with a reservoir of substance which endures throughout the film. The colours and look of the film are all very exaggerated and oversampled, i'm not going to lie, but with such a masterfully woven story, the two go together like Eggs and Bacon, although I doubt highly that Samurai swords are edible.

The brilliance that lies in Kill Bill is that it doesn't overreach itself. It's a revenge flick with a lot of different elements, but it doesn't try to be something else, or pass itself off as a grand odyssey. Likewise, Tarantino as always adds fantastic dialogue which especially helps the Deadly Viper Assassination Squad during the backstory segmints of the movie. Quentin doesn't just want to make films seriously, he also knows that he can also have fun during the process which is something that a few directors twice his age at the time of Kill Bill have yet to understand or even grasp at it's base sense. 

Quentin's casting choices for Kill Bill don't drop the bar either - Uma Thurman returns to the "Tarantinoverse" as The Bride, after previously playing Mia Wallace in Pulp Fiction, as does Michael Madsen after previously appearing in Reservoir Dogs as the sociopathic Mr Blonde. Lucy Liu, Darryl Hannah, and Vivica A. Fox all play fellow members of the Deadly Vipers and succeed in establishing that O-Ren Ishii, Elle Driver and Vernita Green are all worthy of the "badass mofo" informal title which comes with being a former Deadly Viper. And finally, Bill, who has very little screen time in this first volume, but is masterfully portrayed by David Carradine who seems to be just as good as his half-brother at portraying a maniacal but composed deadly killer. 

Kill Bill is at it's root, a revenge flick, but at the same time so much more than just that term. It explores territory many others haven't, is loaded with memorable scenes and characters, and a piece of cinematic paradise in terms of the showdown between The Bride and the Crazy 88's.

Tarantino's 2 part homage to Asian and Western cinema, has indeed came under a considerable amount of flack from critics and fans alike, however in retrospect this vibrant and at times excellent homage to his influences has so much on offer, its very hard to hold Kill Bill in such a high disregard. When a former assassin decides to flee her occupation, cutting all ties from her past and trying to settle down and start a family with a normal man, she soon finds herself left for dead and on a war path that will leave anyone who has shares in cleaning products, extremely delighted. Kill Bill Vol 1 is a one hundred mile per hour, violent and homage filled affair, with in jokes aplenty. Taratino is in full fan boy mode, trying to pack in as many bit parts for legends of Asian cinema, taking influence from Game Of Death and crafting an ambitious finale that will most likely be remember for some time to come. Underneath all this however is a very thin and somewhat mucky concept, yes the character of The Bride is indeed a captivating hero, with Uma Thurman crafting the best heroine in forever, with a brilliant motivation and quirky execution, its hard to fault what her and QT deliver here. The same could be said with some of the supporting characters and indeed stories, Bill is a wonderful antagonist, complex and indeed frightening, his ability to be a father figure and lovable makes his actions even more forceful, equally Lucy Lu as the vicious Tokyo warlord also packs not only a strong punch but a wealth of laughs and memorable quotes. The rest of the cast do an admirable job, the problem clearly stems from the over all goal here. Kill Bill has taken a tale that really should be at most, around the 2 hour mark and stretched it so thinly across 2 films and 4 hours. It becomes evident that by the time Kill Bill Vol 1, finally finds its footing it is over, leaving us stacking up an entire plethora of moments that could indeed be cut to make this 1 solid outing. Stepping away from expectations, whats on offer here is brilliant by many makers, the film is gorgeous, full of brilliant colour, excellent framing, well choreographed fight sequences, vibrant buckets of blood, an anime-esque feel to everything and a wealth of comedy and heart that is impossible to ignore. Every act of violence in Kill Bill, is in some cases justified and indeed packing a punch, especially when the film comes close to wrapping up with the insane finale, that will leave gore hounds in a state of euphoria. There is a huge amount on offer here, and if taken on face value, Kill Bill Vol 1 offers enough to get fans wanting more, the problems begin to show however upon closer inspection, and repeated viewing will indeed push the cracks as far as they can stand. An excellent piece of pulp, bright, funny and quirky but lacking the execution we need for a classic. What it does right however will leave most film makers ashamed of their abilities.

I have been watching Tarantino's films in chronological order by release date in preparation for The Hateful Eight. After the intricate drama which was Jackie Brown, Tarantino returns to the use of violence with Kill Bill Vol. 1, and he adds so much more violence to the film than any of his previous 3. We have Kill Bill Vol. 1 using violence as a spectacle in many ways, especially in the climactic "chapter" of the film.

Like Jackie Brown, Tarantino decides to go with a female protagonist to portray the powerful woman in modern society. Feminism is a large motif in the first part of the whole bloody affair. Yes, The Bride fights men in this film, but the film's main antagonists are strong women who have worked alongside The Bride in the past. The battles are no longer fought by men, guys; the women in this film put men in their place as they are intelligent, maniacal, but above all, simply bad-a**es.

Whereas Reservoir Dogs, Pulp Fiction and Jackie Brown were more "intelligent" films, this one is probably one of the most fun Tarantino movies to watch. It also has a simple premise/motivation which we have seen often before: revenge. But revenge has never been done quite like this. The blood effects in this film are ridiculous beyond any form of rationality, making certain deaths gruesome but at the same time, somewhat pleasing in a twisted fashion. Not only is anime employed to highlight the background of Lucy Liu's character - Tarantino gets away with huge uses of blood in a more "appropriate" manner than if he were to form these scenes as live action segments. It also adds to the idea that the movie is supposed to be fun and cartoonish.

Whereas I have discussed that Tarantino uses dialogue in his first three films to build characters, there is not much "interesting" dialogue in this film as much as narrations by The Bride, but this film doesn't seem to need the witty, clever dialogue we are so used to in Quentin Tarantino films.

With an astounding cliffhanger of an ending, this film makes you crave for more as the credits roll. This is a fun piece of feminist film to say the least, even if the film is desperate for flashbacks and narration at certain moments.

I was never much of a kung-fu guy, revenge flick guy and probably many of the references were lost to me but what separates a great filmmaker from and average one is that this movie niche should be enjoyed by everyone and those said references should never get in the way of a movie experience. Tarantino is a great film maker and Kill Bill is a blast from start to finish.

True, this might be the less inspired movie he's made so far when it comes to dialogues, instantly classic characters and it plods a little on the desert sequence but I'll be damned if I didn't enjoy every single bit of it. From the explosions of stylistic over the top gore, to the incredible cinematography, to the sheer brilliance of the pacing (giving us new things at every turn), Kill Bill is a difficult movie for those who won't be able to appreciate some of the camp and out of nowhere violent jolts, but all of this weird soup fortunately works together.

I loved this all much more the second time around and I bet I'll love it more on my third.
